title: How many British prime ministers were Scottish? - Quora

response.answer_text: There have been 9 Scottish UK prime ministers: John Stuart  26 May 1762 – 8 April 1763 Tory George Hamilton-Gordon  19 December 1852 - 30 January 1855 Peelite (Tory breakaway faction) William Gladstone (though born in England)  15 August 1892 – 2 March 1894 Liberal (though had also been a member of the Tories, Peelites and Conservatives, the successor to the Tories, hence the nickname) Arthur Balfour  11 July 1902 – 5 December 1905 Conservative Henry Campbell-Bannerman  5 December 1905 – 3 April 1908 Liberal Bonar Law (though born in Canada)  23 October 1922 – 22 May 1923 Conservative Ramsey MacDonald  5 June 1929 – 7 June 1935 Labour Tony Blair  2 May 1997 – 27 June 2007 Labour Gordon Brown  27 June 2007 – 11 May 2010 Labour There have also been numerous UK Prime Ministers who were either brought up in Scotland, moved to Scotland at one point, represented constituencies in Scotland or were/are of Scottish descent (i.e Harold Macmillan, David Cameron, etc). It’s possible I’ve missed a few.

More than you’d imagine. Brown and Blair were both Scottish-born. If John Smith would have ever become Prime Minister, so was he. Alec Douglas-Home was born in London, but from landed gentry rooted in the borders. Macmillan was possibly one generation too far from being considered Scottish (as indeed is David Cameron) despite the obviously Scottish name. Ramsay Macdonald was pretty darn Scottish. Bonar Law was born in Canada, but his father was a minister of the Free Church of Scotland. And finally Henry Campbell-Bannerman. So I would argue six from 1905 onwards if you work on the basis as to whether they could play for the Scottish football team. And then going back, Gladstone was born in Liverpool but both parents were Scottish. And The Earl of Aberdeen. If you expand your question to include the major offices of state (Chancellor, Home Secretary, Foreign Secretary), I’m pretty certain Scotland has a fair representation.
